conclusion: Determine the vertical distance d that the point light source S should be moved upward so that the light emitted from S is just not visible above the water surface.
This situation occurs when the light rays from S reach the critical angle at the water surface, causing total internal reflection.
The critical angle is the angle of incidence in the denser medium (water) at which the angle of refraction in the less dense medium (air) is 90 degrees.
Using Snell's Law, the critical angle is calculated as theta_c = 45 degrees.
When the light source is at the critical angle, the light ray travels along the surface of the water, forming a right triangle with the depth H and the radius r of the circular board.
Using trigonometry, tan(theta_c) = r/H, and since theta_c = 45 degrees, we get H = r.
The initial depth of the light source is H = sqrt(3)r.
To make the light just not visible, the depth should be H = r, so the light source needs to be moved upward by d = (sqrt(3) - 1)r.
The point source S should be moved vertically upward by a distance of (sqrt(3) - 1)r so that the light emitted from S is just not visible above the water surface.
